results.location_name: Elgin, Illinois, USA

results.notes:
Habitat:
Where does it grow? woods, in the state of illinois growing on a large rotting section of tree (a big rotting log)

gills:
yellow to yellow orange, adnate gills breaking away easily from stem with age

Stem:
Length 50 mm, diameter 4-6 mm, ochreous ornage with red fibrils that seem to turn purple when the stem is damaged, fibrous smooth besides fibrils, hollow, relatively thick considering size of mushroom, cylindrical to oval in cross-section, somewhat clavate to even etc. no annulus

Cap:
20-40mm, red caps on pins and young specimens to orange and darker in the center on larger ones, texture not smooth crackly (?) scurfy maybe, half spherical with wavy edges in maturity

Spore print color:
Pale rusty tan

Bruising:
reddish to purplish

Other information:
Scent of the mushroom: indistinct, tasting a bit it is NOT bitter. Sort of delicate flavor, slightly sweet, very mealy
results.location_name: Elgin, Illinois, USA

results.notes:
Habitat:
Where does it grow? On a well-manicured lawn outside a public field near a sidewalk where I normally find panaeolus cinctulus and dog-walkers

gills:
attached, adnate, medium close, very dark brown almost black etc.

Stem:
Length: 50-65mm, diameter 1.5-2mm, color: grayish cream, smooth fibrous yet fragile, hollow, cylindrical with vibrant blue mycelial cells at base

Cap:
Diameter: 20-25mm, color: grayish cream, texture smooth with slightly shiny thin fibrous layer over pileus, half-spherical at maturity

Spore print color:
tar black

Bruising:
Color that the mushroom bruises, with age graying at margin on cap and same at base, a slate gray.

Other information:
smell not significant, taste: like a common button mushroom, appetizing. Have not done thorough microscopy but did take a peek at the spores. They appear smooth, by and large citriform with an apical germ pore though it did appear some had an eccentric germ pore. variations in shape included tear drop and I suspect at different angles I saw subglobose and flattened ellipsoid shapes.
results.location_name: Elgin, Illinois, USA

results.notes:
Habitat:
In grasses underneath two large pine trees, in a hilly area near newer homes and woods. In Northern IL.

Gills:
Fresher specimens have pale yellow gills with violet on gill edges while mature and drying specimens begin to have more and more purple/magenta which finally ends in a dark purple with rusty orange nearest pileus edge. Due to the state of specimens (beginning to dry in the sun) I was unable to determine the attachment conclusively)

Stem:
Length abt. 60-90 mm, diameter in younger specimens 10-15 mm and in older 15-25 mm, buff in color with purple fibers fading into a nearly 100% purple stem at the base, texture of younger specimens flexible yet hard with a hollow center in older specimens flexible, soft, and filled with fluff (can’t think of any other term) Stipes are all cylindrical to clavate. Staining a dark purple blue. Think black eye. Additionally these mushrooms all had moveable annuli.

Cap:
Diameter of smallest specimen approximately 50 mm and of largest specimen nearly 150 mm, color of fresh specimens buff with purple brown adpressed scales aging specimens the buff back drop of the pileus becomes magenta with a darker purple brown adpressed scale texture, the texture of the mushroom like a freshly baked fluffy biscuit (roll not cookie for those over the pond), cap shape widely bell shaped with a large prominent umbo becoming nearly plane with age while maintaining umbo.

Spore print color:
Originally found these to have an orange spore print, but all I can think is that my naïve idea to wet these had me end up with a false print. I saved a drying specimen and after checking it weeks later found a massive pile of white spores.

Bruising:
The cap stains magenta. The stipe stains a dark magenta and on pinching a purple-blue stain reminiscent of a human bruise.

Other information:
Smells kind of sweet and doughy.
results.location_name: Elgin, Illinois, USA

results.notes:
Growing on Tsuga heterophylla.
I have noticed that a bunch of live, mature Tsuga have been falling down or breaking off up to 30’ up on the trunk literally like dominoes through this forest, I can walk 1/4mi. stretches on recently fallen logs only setting foot on the ground a few times. It is quite the phenomenon to witness (or picture) the way this fungus is also “walking” through the forest.
The white rot is evident far up the trunk even when these trees first fall down, still bearing green needles. Of course the fruit bodies only show up long after the tree has fallen, like the featured example, this one is well established on a log that has been down for ~20yrs

—See also Observation 231168

results.notes:
Found by Shellie Moubray while we were looking for morels: 10 to 15 growing in damp soil and leaf litter; not seen elsewhere. Cap smooth, radially fibrillose, hygrophanous, with slight depression in center; heavily pigmented concolorus flesh in cap and gills turning black on drying, margin dark brown /black. Gills dull orange matching cap and forked with heavy bloom of white spores, blunt, attached to stem. Structures between and at base of gills highly figured.
Stem translucent dull red-orange brown quickly becoming dull, hollow, basal mycelium white. KOH on cap 4 hours later – greenish. No record of a specimen of this species in MycoPortal.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146011939 on January 6, 2023.

results.notes:
Growing on all 4 hooves of an Odocoileus hemionus columbianus skeleton.
Judging by the algae growth, covering of moss/duff, & state of decay of the hoof material, this deer appears to have suffered its fate a year or three before the deer featured in Observation 271981, which is about 5 or 6 hundred yards away.

Tip for finding this species: The bone featured is part of the ankle/heel called the astragalus, I have been collecting astragali fossils & bones long before I ever heard of Onygena. Anyhoo, I locate this bone, which is often detached from the rest the skeleton by scavengers but is easily identifiable, and I carefully lift it out of the surrounding debris, IF the hoof material was still attached when the carcass was fresh and allowed to decompose without molestation to the degree that most would find it easy to pick this bone up by hand then the hoof (normally the color of dirt, therefore NOT so identifiable at a glance) will be forming one side of the depression that remains after you lift the astragalus. You can stick your finger or a twig down into that depression and lift the hoof remains similarly from the debris.
I have never found O. equina until I have lifted the hoof from the surrounding debris & it seems unlikely that one could find the hoof without first locating the astragalus.
I hope this helps others find this cool fungus!

results.notes:
These specimens show the distinctive macro-morphology of this species.

Kuo’s original description was from Oregon; 7 out of 7 individual fbs showed this unique morphology. They could have been merely “individual” variation, from a single mycelium, since all of Kuo’s examples came from the same general area … the fact of identical morphology in CA collections indicates that this is a good macromorph feature.

There will always be some variability, but 7 out of 7 is statistically significant, and is confirmed by similar examples far out of the range of the original Kuo collections.

Hugh noticed the morpho differences right away in the field, and documented them. He then sent his examples to Clowez, which were they were described in Clowez’s major French paper on worldwide morel species by host tree. DNA was run on these a few years later, matching the Kuo “capitata” samples.

As mentioned here before, capitata is one of the burn morels that can be told apart by other burn morels by both macro and micro means.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1043/2017_DSC7186

Habitat: alpine Fagus sylvatica forest with some Picea abies; in shade, rather cool and humid place; locally almost flat terrain; calcareous, colluvial, stony ground; elevation 950 m, average temperature 5-7 deg C, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: heavily decayed Poliporaceae on fallen off, rotten branch of Fagus sylvatica

Place: Zadnjica valley west of Mt. Triglav, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: I found this ascomycete on heavily decayed pore layer of a Poliporaceae. Phellinus punctatus and Inonotus nodulosus seem most probable at this regions. First I thought I found Nectria peziza (since on polypore). However, spores proved to be too big and too tuberculate. Also perithecia seem pyriforme rather than globose and they apparently do not degrade to widely open ‘peziza’ type cups when old as I expected. Surprisingly I was unable to find asci? In the literature available to me I found no fit to this find. Thanks to the help obtained at AscoFrance (Ref.:1) the find was determined as Cosmospora coccinea. The fungus grows almost exclusively on Inonotus nodulosus decayed pore layer.

Spores tuberculate. Dimensions: 14.3 [16.5 ; 17.6] 19.8 × 8.6 [10.2 ; 11] 12.6 microns; Q = 1.3 [1.6 ; 1.7] 1.9; N = 24; C = 95%; Me = 17 × 10.6 microns; Qe = 1.6. Olympus CH20, NEA 40x/0.65, magnification 400x (all pictures except:), Bausch & Lomb, 4x/0.10, magnification 40x (whole perithecia), in water, fresh material; Novex, Zoom Stereo RZ_Range, Holland (macro pictures of habit). AmScope MA500 digital camera.

results.notes:
This a is about another Rinodina sp. new to me: R. roboris!
My last observations of Rinodina gave me a lesson: Some of the species in this genus are very similar to Lecanora spp. and the subtle difference, if any, refers to the margin of the apothecia, in general more crenulate in relation to Lecanora. Also the chemistry can be the same. Species in Rinodina are either K- or K+yellow, as well as many Lecanora. Thus, my present strategy is: in case of doubt, collect the specimen.

In the present case, perhaps it was a chance maneuver, but what is certain is that it worked out right. In my understanding, it could be a Lecanora, but resulted in a Rinodina roboris, a species that never previously identified and, in a way, is also similar to R. oleae. According to the British Flora, the characteristics of this species are:
- Thallus:grey-green, more or less granular; K+ yellow;
- Apothecia lecanorine with crenulate margins, size up to 1.5 mm in diameter;
- Ascospores of Pachysporaria-type of medium size, for which I got the following dimensions (Sp. 1):
(13.3) 13.7 – 16.1 (17.3) × (7.4) 7.9 – 8.9 (9.7) µm
Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 2 (2.2) ; N = 38; Me = 14.9 × 8.4 µm ; Qe = 1.8.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1047/2017_DSC7374

Habitat: mountain pasture with a standalone group of three Larix decidua trees, slightly inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; open, sunny, relatively warm place; calcareous colluvial, skeletal ground; partly protected from direct rain precipitations by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 600 m (1.970 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: thin dry branch of Larix decidua.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, near cottage Trenta 2b, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comment: Hypogymnia physodes is one of the most common lichens in the region. In Trenta valley one can find it most often on branches and trunks of conifers, particularly of solitary or in small group standing Larix decidua trees. Sometimes the trees appear grayish from far because of it. It grows almost everywhere on different substrata including trees, rocks, moss, heather stems, etc.. Because it is present almost everywhere and medium sensitive for air pollution, it plays a major role in such studies. It excellently ‘measures’ air pollution with heavy metals. My pictures show the lichen in almost dry state, however, the Picture 2 shows the same specimen as the Picture 1, but after a rainy day. The color of the lichen changes significantly from bluish to greenish.

results.notes:
Pileus: 4-4.5cm, convex to plano convex, extremely glutinus cap with glutinus remnants attaching to stipe in strings. Ixocutis approx. 1-2mm thick. Debris on stipe base but not viscid or glutinus at time of collection. Margin even, Disc light brown, coloration uneven bicolorous toward margin gray/cream. Margin smooth. Pileus weakly (span of 48 hours) hygrophorous.

Stipe: 4-7.5cm, 14-15mm width, even, with radicating base. Soil adhearing to bottom 3rd of radicating stipe portion. Concentric appressed squamulose upper half of stipe yellow brown to coffee brown along upper half of stipe. Apex 3mm from lamellea remnants of “cortina” brown ephemeral annulus. Context stuffed with some with small hollow at base. Base lower 5-10mm quickly staining rust brown after bisection. Radicating portion of stipe white with small pubescent hairs adhering substrate to stipe.

Lamellae:Arcuate-subdecurrent, crowded, 2 series,moderately broad, Color: concolorus with cap when young grayish cream, rusty orange brown with age. margin of gill smooth

Odor-Taste:mild to bitter after 20 seconds, odor mildly Phenolic
Spore Deposit: Rusty coffee brown

Substrate: Volcanic cinder, coming from duff of Pinus Radiata, Cupressus lusitanica, Acacia mearnsii, and Rubrus.

results.notes: This one group of Amanitas was different to what I normally see. They were in a very shaded low light area under canopy and in dense ground cover with only the caps slightly showing. When I cleared the area to take some photos I was struck by the delicate state of the specimens. All were almost unable to stand freely and when I attempted to remove them from their habitat the Volvas were easily separated from the stipes. There was not the usual large rounded shape, but more of a thick loose volva wrapping at the stipe base. There was also a shredding effect at the point of separation of the volvas from the stipes. The stipes were white in colour and almost transparent but not reaching that stage. The ground was wet and the forest floor plant life looked healthy. The condition of the fungi could have been due to the wet period we have had and also the low level of daylight available to the fungi. I still collected the three fungi very carefully , but by the time I had arrived home they were disintegrating and loosing moisture. I was unable to save them as dried specimens. This was disappointing I must say, but then I surmised that maybe the local conditions were responsible for the appearance I noted.
results.location_name: Yarrahapinni State Forest, North of Grassy Head, New South Wales, Australia

results.notes:
On decorticated wood in shade, a large stump of Eucalyptus globulus I think.

Four specimens are shown here all collected from the same stump. These are tiny, with apothecia less than 0.5mm (yes, I need to get a scale bar on these photos, they are all shot at the same scale so visual comparisons of size are valid). I assume these specimens represent more than one species, but I haven’t done the micro yet. In the field I thought #3 was something like Lecanora strobilina.

EDIT: Micro photos and details in the comment are from Specimen #5. All others tested very similar and I could not determine that this collection represents different species.

results.notes: Noisy chromatogram on this specimen but ITS blast results show all of these to be in the SW Clade of the Fomitopsis pinicola complex as defined by Haight 2013 which confirmed the existence of 4 species well-supported by multi-locus phylogenetic analysis: F. pinicola, restricted to Eurasia; F. ochracea, restricted to NA; and two previously undescribed NA species from NA—NAA from northern NA and SW Clade from southwestern NA. However, the study was unable to rule out the possibility of a subclade in the SW Clade: “This study contains insufficient data to determine the validity of the subclade within the Southwest Clade in the coalescent species tree. More data should be collected from specimens in this geographic region to help answer this question.” There appear to be SNP’s in at least 4 positions of this portion of the gene which account for most of the differences between the various AZ collections (1 fixed difference in 2 cases): MO 274489 (doug. fir), 272531 (aspen), 287443 (pond. pine), 272532 (conifer), 274487 (aspen), 287444 (conifer). Reverse sequence would confirm.

results.notes:
This is a series showing the aging of Neofomitopsis spraguei from 2016-08-03 to 2016-09-06, of the caps initially submitted at: mushroomobserver.org/246501
Notes: Brackets growing at the base (east and north sides) of a live oak tree (Quercus sp.) growing on the east-facing shore (receives morning/midday sun; shaded in the afternoon) of a reservoir.
Caps. Occurring in clusters. Largest cap ca. 6 inches wide, and approximately 3/8 inches thick at the margin. White/off-white with orange-brown margins.Cap surfaces rough/irregular with detritus embedded in tops of caps. Droplets of fluid near margins on top and underside.
Pore surface white. Pores angular, 4-6/mm.

I made a search at this place to know if there were more specimens and, in the affirmative case, how they were distributed. My conclusion was that, at least here, it seems to be host specific, having Ligustrum lucidum as host.
I found more specimens at the same tree than those in observation 274252, considered at this observation, and a group of other specimens at another tree of the same species, curiously placed in front of that in my previous observation on the other side of a road (to be consider at another observation). I was not able to see any other specimens around.

results.notes:
Awaiting spore drop. But in the meantime I smash-mounted a bit of material and found spores that may have been squeezed out of asci (not sure if this makes sense), or maybe they’re still inside asci. Material mounted in cotton blue, which seems to have been a good choice. Projections at either end of a spore are nicely highlighted in the stain (at least I think that’s what the photo shows).

Immature spores viewed in smash mount 26-28 × 9-11 not including the projections. Mature spores from spore drop 27-34 × 9-13 including the knobs, which are more easily discerned on the mature spores.

If I get a spore drop I’ll re-check the spore morphology.

results.notes:
I returned to the place of observation 237388 (see also observation 110992) and looked at the original tree and the others closer to make “an inventory of stocks”. I concluded that each of the trees in the group have specimens of this species, some very poorly develepod.
Meanwhile, I identified the trees, as Celtis australis, a rather common and native species here, which in the case was used to forest a neighborhood in a recent urbanization.
My impression in the field was that there was a regression in relation to my observation last year and the appearance is more like when I observed the specimens for the first time, since the stelate fruit bodies are barely visible.
Let’s wait to see what the microscopy has to tell.

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura entre 500 – 600 msnm; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura entre 500 – 600 msnm; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

results.notes: These were originally found a couple of weeks ago growing in clumps, in grass around a mailbox at the side of a road through the woods. Now, with wetter weather, they are coming up singly and in pairs. None, no matter how immature, feature any evidence of a partial veil on cap margin or stipe. Caps are dry, not sticky even when moistened, often cracked. Cap diameter of the largest specimen in the photo is 43 mm. Stipe width at the narrow midpoint is 5 mm. The stipe of the conical, less mature specimen is 11 mm wide. Gills are notched to adnate, speckled with brown and showing a white fringed edge barely visible in the photo. Stipe is stuffed then hollow. No rhizoids at base. Odor farinaceous. Taste farinaceous then slightly bitter. Spore print dull, medium brown. KOH on cap is dark brown. Agrocybe vervacti is an alternative ID. It lacks a partial veil but is supposed to be a bit smaller and lack the farinaceous odor.

results.notes:
[PNW Key Council Foray at Lake Cowichan]

Growing on a mossy log, not thick and with bark. It could be Alnus, but there were a lot of conifers around too. Collected on a rainy day, no photo in situ taken, no odor recorded. “Dense bloom giving the cap a pale-bluish sheen” — a character Smith used in the description of the type, and later used to distinguish the species from similar lignicolous Fragilipedes (M. abramsii, M. alclaliniformis) — was not observed, perhaps because of the rain and handling. Other than this, everything seems to match, in particular relatively short spores, gills adnate without decurrent tooth, and the variety of cheilocystidia shapes as depicted in Maas Geesteranus’s study. The type collection of M. alicola is from just a little South, in the Olympic Nat’l Park.

Basidia 4-spored 25-30 + 4.5 × 8. Spores 7.5-8.5 × 4.5-5; Q in the range 1.6-1.8. Cheilocystidia typically 40-50 × 11-15, most of them with a longish neck in the two caps examined.
